1.
INTRODUCTION
License PL 150, Block 24/9 is operated by Fina Exploration Norway Inc. on behalf of the following group:
Fina Exploration Norway (Operator) Statoil Enterprise Oil Norge Ltd. Saga Petroleum a.s.
10% 50% 30% 10%
Well 24/9-6 was spudded on the 1st of February 1994 by the semisubmersible rig "West Delta". The well reached a total depth (TD) of 2255.Om BRT on the 28th February 1994. The formation at TD was the Upper Palaeocene, Heimdal Formation.
Well 24/9-6 was drilled to appraise the 25/9-5 discovery and was plugged and abandoned as an oil well, without testing, after encountering oil in a Balder Formation sandstone reservoir.

2.
OBJECTIVES
Well 24/9-6 was programmed to test an Upper Palaeocene Balder Formation sandstone objective. The well was designed to appraise the 24/9-5 discovery well and is located 2.2 km to the east of the 24/9-5 well location (Fig. 2.1).
Well 24/9-5 encountered a thin, 5.9m net, Balder Sandstone reservoir. The well was not considered to be optimally placed for the Balder Formation objective and no production tests were made. Instead well 24/9-6 was drilled as an immediate appraisal in an optimum location to the east of the 24/9-5 location. Mapping indicated that sandstone presence within the Balder Formation could be identified by gross Balder Formation thickening and by an associated seismic amplitude anomaly, believed to be a direct hydrocarbon indicator. Well 24/9-6 was located close to the centre of the Balder Formation interval thickening in a position where the seismic amplitude anomaly was best developed (Fig. 2.2).

3.
RESULTS
Hydrocarbons were encountered in Balder Formation sandstones however the accumulation was concluded to be of sub-commercial size and the well was plugged and abandoned without production testing.
The first Balder Formation sandstone was penetrated at 2004.Om, 10m high to prognosis. The gross interval was 20m thicker than predicted. Two massive sandstone units were encountered with a total net thickness of 49.5m (prognosis 25m). A thin (0.5m) oil-bearing sandstone was encountered of 2004.Om and at 2010.5m a 10.5m thick hydrocarbon-bearing sandstone was penetrated. A lower massive sandstone unit penetrated at 2034.Om was 38m thick, however it proved to be water-bearing. No oilwater contact (OWC) was encountered, oil down to (ODT) was seen at 2021m and highest known water (HKW) at 2034.Om, thin sandstones in the interval 2029.0-2033.Om exhibit good shows in core.
Analysis of a PVT sample from 2012.Om shows the oil gravity to be 32º API with a gas/oil ratio (GOR) of 592 scf/bbl. PVT pressure data indicates the fluid system to be saturated or near saturation at reservoir conditions. However no indications of the presence of a gas cap were seen.

4.
STRATIGRAPHY
4.1
LITHOSTRATIGRAPHY
The principal lithostratigraphic units were identified using lithological samples and biostratigraphic analysis. Formation tops were refined using wireline and MWD logs. The lithostratigraphic nomenclature is as per Isaksen and Tonstad with minor amendments. Subdivisions of the Hordaland Group as published by the Robertson Group (1989) have been incorporated. The intra Sele Formation sandstones are termed the Hermod and Teal Members as is the practise in the adjacent areas of the UK sector. The term Teal Member was also introduced by the Robertson Group (1989) and is equivalent to the Forties Formation of the Central Graben.
The following formation descriptions are based on cuttings, sidewall core and core samples, wireline log motifs are described where relevant. No cuttings samples were recovered above 1286m and so the stratigraphy has been interpreted from wireline and MWD logs, and by correlation with offset well data. The lithostratigraphic succession is summarised in the table below. Figure 4.1 summarises the actual versus the prognosis stratigraphy.

NORDLAND GROUP
152.5 - 658.Om
The lithology and boundaries of the Nordland Group have been interpreted from MWD and wireline logs.
Unamed Quaternary
152.5 - 222.0m
This interval was picked on the pilot hole MWD gamma ray as a predominantly clay interval which is correlated with a similar near surface interval in Well 24/9-5.
Utsira Formation
222.0 - 658.Om
The top of this interval was picked on the pilot hole MWD gamma ray as a downhole reduction reflecting a change to dominantly sandstone lithology.
HORDALAND GROUP
658.0 - 1917.5m
The top of the Hordaland Group has been picked by correlation of MWD logs with Well 24/9-5.
The Hordaland Group comprises a shallowing upward sequence from upper bathyl to middle shelf environment. The group is dominated by massive claystones and siltstones. Sandstone intervals occur at several levels particularly within the Lark Formation
Lark Formation
658.0 - 1144.Om
Wireline data indicates this interval to be interhedded sandstone and claystone. Sandstones are well developed in the uppermost part of the interval, below 945.Om claystone is the predominant lithology.
Horda Formation
1144.0 - 1772.0m
The top of this formation would normally coincide with a Top Eocene hiatus. As no samples are available over this interval and a monotonous argillaceous clastic sequence is seen on the logs the prognosis Top Eocene depth is given. Sandstone development is seen within the Grid Formation and Belton Member. Below 1286.Om medium olive brown and green grey, blocky siltstones were described, these grade to claystone below 1500.Om.

Grid Formation
1157.0 - 1271.0m
On MWD and wireline logs an overall fining up sequence is recognised. Four main sandstone intervals are identified, the lowest from 1244.0 - 1271.Om is the best developed. A good correlation is seen with Well 24/9-5.
Belton Member
1323.0 - 1350.Om
A single massive sandstone unit with a sharp top and base. It was described as quartz, fine to very fine grained, moderately sorted, generally loose, cemented in part.
Frigg Formation Equivalent
1772.0 - 1917.Om
The "Frigg Formation Equivalent" actually represents the Lower Frigg Unit sensu stricto. The top of the interval is identified by a flooding surface gamma ray peak followed by a slight increase in background gamma ray and resistivity values. A second flooding surface can be identified at 1842.Om. The interval comprises grey claystones and siltstones deposited in an upper bathyl environment during an overall transgressive phase. No sandstone development was seen.
ROGALAND GROUP
1917.0 - 2255.Om
Balder Formation
1917.0 - 2088.Om
The top of the Balder Formation is identified on logs by a flooding surface gamma ray peak, followed by slight decrease in background gamma ray and resistivity values. The formation top was confirmed by the biostratigraphy. The Balder Formation can be conveniently divided into two gross units; an upper "Balder Claystone" interval and a lower "Balder Tuff" interval. The reservoir sandstone development occurs within the "Balder Tuff" interval. In Well 24/9-6 an Upper Massive Sandstone Unit and a Lower Massive Sandstone Unit were encountered within the "Balder Tuff" interval. The Balder Formation was 20 thicker than prognosis, this thickening is accounted for by greater than predicted sandstone development.
Balder Claystone
1917.0 - 1980.Om
The "Balder Claystone" interval comprised medium olive brown to green grey claystone, soft to firm, occasionally tuffaceous, occasionally silty/sandy with traces of pyrite, non to slightly calcareous. It is interpreted as being deposited in a restricted bathyl environment.

Balder Tuff
1980.0 - 2088.Om
The top of the "Balder Tuff" interval was identified on MWD and wireline data as slight decrease in background gamma ray levels and by an increase in resistivity. The unit consists of hemipelagic claystones interbedded with fallout tuffs and minor distal turbidites. Within the interval are developed "grain flow" sandstones primarily in two massive units from 2010.5-2021.Om and from 2034.0-2072.Om.
The claystones are described as medium to dark grey, firm to hard, blocky to fissile, in part laminated with, and grading to, cemented, tuffaceous siltstone and very fine sandstone (distal turbidites, generally < 5 cm thick). The tuffs are variously olive grey, medium grey, light grey and medium bluish grey and are generally clay to silt grade.
The Upper Massive Sandstone Unit is 10.5m thick and is described as fine to medium grained, well sorted, subangular to subround quartz grains, unconsolidated, claystone clasts are visible in core material above a loaded base, porosity is excellent. Limited core data and Hexdip/CBIL data indicates it to be internally massive and structureless.
The Lower Massive Sandstone Unit is considerably thicker (38m) and may represent a number of accreting depositional pulses. The upper 9.5m of this unit was cored and is described as massive, fine to medium grained, well sorted, subangular to subround quartz, rare felspar, common pyrite development near the top of the unit, generally unconsolidated but partially to well cemented in part, excellent porosity when not cemented. Wireline logs and cuttings show the interval 2055.0 - 2063.Om to be tight with carbonate cemented sandstone interbeds up to 1.7m thick.
Thin sandstones with similar characteristics to the massive sandstone units were encountered in the interval 2021.0 - 2034.Om and also at 2004.Om, maximum individual bed thickness is 1.7m.
Sele Formation
2088.0 - 2154.Om
The Sele Formation was encountered 20m deep to prognosis at 2088.Om. The top of the Sele Formation is marked by a downhole increase in gamma ray values. The formation can be divided into a series of units based on flooding surfaces identified by gamma ray peaks and the presence of sandstones.
An upper interval from 2088.0 - 2118.5m comprises medium to dark grey claystone which is firm, generally subfissile, locally microlaminated, generally slightly silty, micromicaceous and slightly carbonaceous. On the basis of the gamma ray this interval can be divided in two; an upper high gamma ray interval from 2088.0-2105.Om (S3 subdivision, as referred to in the 24/9 correlation study) and a lower gamma ray interval from 2105.0-2118.5m (S2 subdivision).
Below the Hermod Member sandstone, claystones again dominate from 2137.0 - 2154.0m (S1 subdivision). The claystones are medium dark grey, blocky to subfissile and locally rich in very fine sand grains. Traces of very fine to fine grained sandstone occur in cuttings at 2148.Om and represent a condensed equivalent of the Teal Member. In the bottom three metres of the Sele Formation a gamma ray peak coincides with dark grey subfissile claystones.

Hermod Member
2118.5 - 2137.Om
A sharp downhole increase in gamma ray values mark the top of a 18.5m thick massive sandstone unit. The sandstone is light grey, fine to medium grained, subround to subangular, friable, generally unconsolidated, heavily carbonate cemented in part, common pyrite cement and pyrite grains. The Hermod Member is equivalent to the lower part of the S2 subdivision of the Sele Formation. It is considered to be submarine grain flow deposit.
Lista Formation
2154.0 - 2210.Om
A downhole decrease in gamma ray values within claystone lithology marks the top of the Lista Formation. The formation comprises medium dark grey, mottled olive grey, medium grey, grey green claystones which are subfissile, moderately micaceous and generally silty.
Heimdal Formation
2210.0 - 2255.0m (TD)
The top of the Heimdal Formation is marked by a change to predominantly coarse clastic deposition. Initially the sandstones are fine grained becoming fine to medium with depth, generally loose, locally with carbonate cement. Thick sandstone units are separated by thin claystone interbeds.
4.2
BIOSTRATIGRAPHY
Biostratigraphic evaluation of the well was performed by Simon Petroleum Technology Ltd. (SPT). Detailed results are contained in a separate report entitled "Fina Exploration Norway, Well 24/9-6 Biostratigraphy of the intervals 1302.0 - 1392.Om and 1698.0 - 2253.0m, May 1994).
Cuttings, core and sidewall core samples were analysed for lithology, micropalaeontology and palynology as follows:
Lithology
7 cuttings samples from the interval 1302.Om and 1392.Om. 42 cuttings samples, 9 sidewall cores and 5 core samples from the section 1698.Om-2253.0m.
Micropalaeontology
:
7 cuttings samples from the interval 1302.Om-1392.Om. 44 cuttings samples, 9 sidewall cores and 5 core samples from the section 1698.0-2253.0m. All micropalaeontological analyses were semi-quantitative.
Palynology
7 cuttings samples from the interval 1302.0m-1392.Om analysed semi-quantitatively. 42 cuttings samples, 9 sidewall cores and 5 core samples from the section 1698.Om-2253.Om all analysed quantitatively.

5.
HYDROCARBON SHOWS
Routine mudlogging commenced in the 12 1/4" hole, below 1286.Om, within the Horda Formation. Above this depth the hole was drilled without returns. No indication of hydrocarbons are seen on the MWD logs from the 8 1/2" pilot hole (to 800.Om) or from the 17 1/2" hole (to 1286.Om).
HORDALAND GROUP
Horda Formation
1144.0 - 1772.Om
Total gas levels ranged from 0.01% at 1286.Om to a maximum of 0.25%. The chromatographic breakdown showed the gas to be primarily C, with C, being present below 1610.Om and C, below 1720.Om. The interval was drilled with mud weight of 1.4-1.6 s.g. The only potential reservoir within this interval is the Belton Member (1323.0-1350.Om). No shows were recorded.
Frigg Formation Equivalent
1772.0 - 1917.Om
The dominantly claystone interval was drilled with a mudweight of 1.5-1.57 s.g. Total gas ranged from 0.06% to 0.6%. Chromatographic breakdown showed C,, C, and Cą to be present, traces of nCA were also detected in the interval 1814.0 to 1837.Om. No shows were recorded.
ROGALAND GROUP
1917.0 - 2255.Om
Balder Formation
1917.0 - 2088.Om
TD of the 12 1/4" hole was reached at 1963.Om. In the 8 1/2" hole section the mudweight was reduced to 1.16-1.18 s.g.
Shows were first observed in a thin sandstone at 2004.0-2004.5m. An Upper Massive Sandstone Unit was encountered from 2010.5-2021.Om. This unit showed 100% light brown oil stain, bright yellow white fluorescence, instant milky white cut fluorescence. Thin sandstones at 2029.15-2029.85m and 2031.4-2033.0m (log corrected core depths) also exhibited good shows described as 100% light brown oil stain, yellow gold fluorescence and instant bright yellow milky white streaming/blooming cut fluorescence. No shows were observed in the Lower Massive Sandstone Unit interval from 2034.0-2072.Om.
Total gas recorded in the Balder Formation ranged from 0.02% to 0.42% and averaged 0.05%. Chromatographic breakdown showed C,, C2, Cz, iCa and nC, to be present.

Sele Formation
2088.0 - 2154.Om
Background total gas levels remained low throughout the Sele Formation interval ranging from 0.03-0.09% in the claystone intervals and dropping to 0.025% in the Hermod Member Sandstone. Chromatographic breakdown showed C, with minor C, to be present. No shows were observed in the Hermod Member Sandstone interval (2118.5-2137.0m).
Lista Formation
2154.0 - 2210.Om
Background total gas levels ranged from 0.025 to 0.065% and consisted primarily of C, with traces of C, recorded. No reservoir intervals were encountered in the Lista Formation interval and no shows were recorded.
Heimdal Formation
2210.0 - 2255.0m (TD)
Background gas levels dropped further on penetrating the main Heimdal sandstone interval averaging 0.025% (principally C,). A high of 0.1% total gas was recorded at 2251m, chromatographic breakdown showed C,, C, and Cą to be present. No shows were recorded.

7.1
CONVENTIONAL CORING
Three conventional cores were cut in the Upper Palaeocene Balder Formation.

Core intervals have been corrected to log depths from drill depth by applying the following corrections:
Core No. 1 Core No. 2 Core No. 3
-1.8m -1.8m -1.8m from 2032.5 - 2035.5m -0.9m from 2035.5 - 2045.1m
Core recovered in core no. 1 is believed to be from the bottom of the cored interval. The inner liner of core no. 3 sheared and it is believed that up to 0.9m may have been lost at 2035.5m (drill depth).
The coring contractor was Baker Hughes Inteq. A "Hydrolift" full closure 3 1/2" core barrel in conjunction with a RC412 low invasion core bit was utilised in an attempt to maximize recovery in the expected unconsolidated sandstones. An 9m barrel was run for core no. 1, 18m barrels were used for core nos. 2 and 3. At surface the plastic inner liners were cut into 1m lengths and immediately resin injected by Geco-Prakla prior to shipment to the laboratory.
Coring procedures relating to coring parameters, tripping and surface handling were implemented to minimize core damage and maximize recovery. However, core recovery in the main reservoir interval was poor with less than 1m of sandstone recovered.
Summary Description
Wellsite core logs are shown in Figs. 7.1 - 7.4, Enclosure 1 is a full core log. Depths on the core log and in the following summary are drill depths.
All core was cut in the Balder Formation.
2022.5 - 2022.8m: The basal Upper Massive Sandstone Unit. Described as massive, fine to medium grained quartz, well sorted, with an irregular loaded base and common clay rip up clasts. Visible porosity is excellent. The core was 100% stained with light brown oil.
2022.8 - 2035.Om: This interval comprises a fining upward sequence. The dominant lithology is laminated claystones interbedded with thin tuffaceous bands. Turbidite and grain flow sandstone interbeds become finer grained upwards and range from 1.7m thick at the base to a few centimetres

bands. Turbidite and grain flow sandstana

at the top of the interval. The sandstones are generally featureless with sharp bases and tops although some sandstone injection features can be seen and clay clasts are common. Sandstones at 2031.0-2031.7m and 2033.2-2034.85m may represent larger scale sand injection features. Oil shows are seen in the sandstone intervals.
2035.6 - 2045.1m: Comprises the top of a massive grain flow sandstone deposit. Described as unconsolidated fine to medium grained, well sorted, predominantly quartz with rare felspar, pyritic modules are common, variably cemented, generally featureless, subparallel laminations were noted at 2040.3m, floating claystone clasts were noted at 2042.5m.
Routine Core Analysis

10.
PETROPHYSICS
Hydrocarbon were encountered in Upper Palaeocene, Balder Formation sandstones. A gross hydrocarbon column of 17m (net 11.1m) was penetrated in the interval 200.4.0 - 2021.0m, 10.5m net pay occurs in the single massive sandstone from 2010.5 - 2021.Om. A lower massive sandstone unit (2034.0 - 2072.0m) was water-bearing, however thin sandstone stringers in the interval 2021.0 - 2034.Om have oil shows in core samples.
No indications of hydrocarbons were seen in any other interval.
Petrophysical analysis was performed using the Western Atlas CRA programme over the interval 2000.0 - 2150.Om. Results are shown in Figs. 10.1 and Enclosure 3.
Data:
Logs used were DPIL, DLL/MLL and ZDEN/CN/GR. Data was of good quality although some borehole rugosity is evident in the interval 2000.0 - 2035.Om.
Analysis:
DLL, RMLL, ZDEN and CN data was acquired in high resolution mode. A light filter was applied before analysis.
The DLL/MLL, ZDEN and CN logs were environmentally corrected before computation.
Rt was calculated from the DLL over the interval 2000.0 - 2035.Om, the DPIL was used below 2035.Om.
Porosity and shale volume were calculated from the density/neutron crossplot.
An Rw of 0.043 ohm at 54°C was estimated from the Rwa computation. Sw was calculated using the Archie equation.

11.
GEOPHYSICAL SURVEY
11.1
SITE SURVEY
The site survey for Well 24/9-6 was carried out by M/V Tridens 1 between the 21st January and 29th January 1994 in Block 24/9 of the Norwegian sector of the North Sea.
The survey area comprised a 4x2.75 km square grid, oriented 018°/108°, covering the 24/9-6 location and several of the proposed anchor locations. The survey lies at the eastern margin of the previous site survey centred over the proposed 24/9-5 well location and covering an area of 5x5 km square.
The purpose of the survey was to collect, process and document seafloor and sub-bottom data for the emplacement of a drilling rig within the survey area.
Analogue data was acquired over a grid totalling 47.5 km and was integrated with the data from the site survey over Well 24/9-5.
Bathymetry: The water depth at the well location is 123.5m MSL (122.7m LAT). Within a 1 km radius of the 24/9-6 location water depths range from 122m MSL in the west to 124m MSL in the east.
Debris: A linear debris item with no discernible height was noted 610m south-east of the well location.
Geological Hazards: At the well location itself there was no shallow gas.
11.2
VSP SURVEY
Downhole Seismic Services conducted a Zero Offset VSP and Fixed Offset VSP in Well 24/9-6. The wireline was provided by Atlas Wireline Services Inc.
The survey began at 13:40 hrs on the 2nd March 1994 and was completed at 06:55 hrs the next day. The weather was reported to be rough for the duration of the survey with force 7 winds.
All measured depths were referenced below Rotary Table (RT) elevation of 29m above MSL. At the time of the survey the well had been drilled to a depth of 2252m RT and cased to a depth of 1957m RT.
Data for this survey consisted of 225 files gathered at 154 levels ranging from 440m to 2245m for the Zero Offset survey and 170 levels in the Fixed Offset survey between 540m and 2230m below RT. Data were acquired at 10m intervals.
The DSS engineer deployed two 70 cu.in. and two 150 cu.in. sleeve guns suspended from a rig crane for Zero Offset source operating at a pressure of 1800 psi. The rig source was positioned 50m from the wellhead, at an azimuth of N229 degrees and at a depth of 10m below mean sea level. The reference geophone was suspended at 12m below mean sea level for timing purposes.
For the Fixed Offset survey, a source array comprising two 70 cu.in. and two 150 cu.in. guns operating at a pressure of 2000 psi was positioned 1300m from the wellhead on an azimuth of 18 degrees and at a depth of 4m below mean sea level. The reference geophone was suspended at 9m below mean sea level.

A multilevel receiver with 5 geophones was used.
With the start of the survey, the wireline depth sensor was zeroed at the RT elevation. The tool was stopped a number of times during the downtrip to check the equipment performance. The bottom tool was eventually lowered to the depth of 2245m RT. Data recording commenced at that depth from the rig source and proceeded as the geophones were subsequently raised to shallower depths. On completion of the survey, the geophones were lowered again to 2230m RT and shooting commenced from the fixed offset boat source.
At each downhole station, the wireline cable was stopped and the surface controlled motor driven arm was activated to lock the geophone tools to the borehole wall. An average of four shots were recorded for each geophone depth level.
During the survey, the geophones were firmly clamped to the borehole wall for all levels occupied.
All VSP data of acceptable quality were included in the processing using the following standard sequence:
Demultiplex Edit noisy traces Correct for geometric spreading Estimation of downwaves Downwave VSP deconvolution Subtract downwaves Remove tube waves Remove shear waves Upwave VSP deconvolution Corridor stack VSP to CDP tranformation Display
-
The final results are of good quality and tie well with the 3D seismic data.
11.3 SYNTHETIC SEISMOGRAMS
The acoustic impedance curve was computed by multiplication of the calibrated acoustic log and the density log. From this a primary reflectivity series was derived, as well as reflectivity series for primary and multiple reflections and multiple reflections only. These reflectivity series were then convolved with the zero phase bandpass filters 12(18)-60(36) Hz (dB/oct) and 12(18)-40(36) Hz (dB/oct) (to match the surface seismic) and displayed at scales of 10 cm/sec and 20 cm/sec.
The well to seismic tie was carried out on the 3D seismic Inline X-1098 using the synthetic seismogram zero phased without multiples and a bandpass wavelet of 12-40 Hz, the Acoustic Impedance log and the Zero Offset VSP (zero phased corridor stack) with a bandpass filter of 12-40 Hz. This is presented in Figure 11.1.
